thanks for this video! but I still have something that confuses me, do we not need to put the negative sign for torque even though the pulley is spinning in the clockwise direction?

Isn't this system one that's more dynamic? if the wheel has a radius of 2m, has an angular acceleration of 2.45 rad/s^2 and the string with tension is affixed to the rightmost point on the circle, then after that point rotates about 3.14 meters around the circumference (after about 2.5 seconds), wouldn't it be at the bottom? How would we be sure that the block would have that speed after 8 seconds if it could be traveling upwards against the force of gravity? Or is the string disconnected from the wheel immediately after pulling it down?

because before we assume that the pulley is ideal which means it's massless and frictionless. In this case, the pulley has mass, so we cannot assume tension is the same throughout the rope

9.8 m/s^2 is the acceleration of gravity on earth. It is denoted by g. problems like these are always using earth's gravity so if you see g it is 9.8
it depends on convention, for the blocks positive is going towards acceleration and positive for the rotating disk is counter clock wise.
Doesn't matter treat it as absolute as long as its not acting against another opposing forces or torques
he makes it negative at 17:53
You can define an arbitrary direction as positive so long as you are consistent with it, similar to how you can set up convenient coordinate axes as you wish
